pros: Able to do homework during shifts
cons: Expected us to get up and check the lab every 10 minutes, felt a little overkill

review_title: Avoid if you don't subscribe to the woke ideology
pros: You work mostly with positive people. Beautiful campus.
cons: The college has succumbed to the woke ideology, and they seem to focus more on that than the actual quality of the education that takes place there. Some of the communications that have been sent out and the groups employees are invited to take part in are racist against white employees - but that doesn't seem to matter as long as they aren't racist to POC. I also saw communication go out that make false claims against the Republican party, which they think is fine because they believe everyone to be a leftist at the college, but that's untrue. What I'm trying to say is, if you are a conservative, steer clear. Unfortunately, the higher education system as a whole is highly intolerant of those with differing points of view.

pros: Freedom in scheduling around classes, good supervisors
cons: Can only work as a student

pros: Opportunity for almost free education, professional development. Beautiful campus. Department co-workers great people - good communication and team work. Supportive Department Head. Rewarding to serve students of all backgrounds.
cons: Trustees and Execs. lack connection with reality. Lower enrollment means budget cuts year after year. Some management and supervisors are terrible. As with any Higher Ed Faculty are treated better than all other employees. Many important roles have been filled on an interim basis. Lower enrollment means layoffs. Many resignations over the last 2 years. Many empty positions not filled so extra work for remaining employees with lack of training. College not open to continued remote work. College not able to enforce its own policies such as a "fully vaccinated campus". College has a history of closing out programs that are enrolled and successful and keeping those that are "favorites" or that attract media attention.

review_title: Fantastic Supervisory Leadership; Executive staff still not listening
job_title: Program Specialist II in Vancouver, WA
pros:
I love my direct team, we have excellent communication and symmetry. 

My direct supervisors are all passionate about the work we do and always willing to communicate.

Student Affairs staff are passionate about student success, equity, and inclusion, across the board!
cons:
Executive staff has improved, but are still not the best at directly communicating changes or expectations of staff.

Position reallocation/job title upgrade via HR is an absolute nightmare, even with full supervisory support.

Executive staff's expectations of our workload is unrealistic, at best. At worst, we need to be in three different places simultaneously.

review_title: Nice people, but not enough work
job_title: ESL Adjunct Instructor in Vancouver, WA
pros: Nice people and wonderful students
cons: Programs ever shrinking, sometimes you get a class or 2, sometimes none, lots of management changes and lack of structure in ESL program - no consistent book used, so hard to see improvement in students. No accountability for students. Too much weight on test scores, but this is due to state requirements, not the college

job_title: Program Support Specialist II in Vancouver, WA
pros:
You get a discount on tuition. 

The institution actually tries to implement diversity and equity instead of just talking about it.

There is no shortage of work.
cons:
You literally never have time to take classes. 

They still do a lot of talking about diversity without action. 

People leave without being replaced and their work is given to the people who remain "while they hire a replacement." Then 6 months later there is no replacement for "budget reasons" and we all just have to absorb their work. I left because I was doing 3 peoples' worth of jobs with no support in sight. I probably screwed my department when I left because they put so many responsibilities on me with literally no backup.

job_title: IT Support Technician II in Vancouver, WA
pros:
Daily tasks vary greatly

You get to assist in a lot of different tier 1 tasks and some tier 2 tasks as well within a given week.
cons:
No benefits, no union, 'right-to-work' for 1050 employees (hourly paid workers)
No real chance of advancement into a full-time position just because you're in part-time position

pros: Good hours, nice students and a reasonable work output expectation
cons: Base pay the same for all part time faculty regardless of experience, no pay raises beyond COL

pros: Some nice individuals; Professional development opportunities
cons: Horrible toxic people with lifelong job security

job_title: Program Support Supervisor in Vancouver, WA
pros:
flexible
student focused
team driven
diverse
helps vulnerable populations
cons:
communication with management
administration lacks equitable student focus

job_title: Full Time Biology Instructor in Vancouver, WA
pros: Most employees are committed to helping students.
cons: Issues with quality and experience of some upper- level administrators and appointed Board of Trustees members; struggling to develop a solid plan for the future and then stick with it.

review_title: Management Not The Best, Coworkers Are Amazing
pros:
The folks you work with love working with and for the students
Benefits are pretty good
cons: Management doesn’t really know what’s going on a lot of the time, but makes a lot of the decisions without consulting the employees that work with students

pros:
We were paid $68 per classroom hour. Not $68 per hour. Most adjuncts are assigned 5 to 8 hours per week.
Day to day work was pleasant. There was mutual respect between colleagues.
cons: Adjuncts are second class citizens who are paid a fraction of the rate full-time professors are, yet we teach 75% of the classes. But worse than that, we are expendable. If you inconvenience or anger someone higher up on the ladder than you, you are out. Also, the president and my department chair went out of there way to talk about how much they appreciated the adjuncts. What a joke!

pros: The unity and camaraderie with staff here is amazing. Most of the students are very sweet! There are people here who genuinely want to see them succeed.
cons: Awful leadership and communication, classified staff worked to the bone with no pay raises or appreciation, and staff being cut left and right. No promotional opportunities. Too many middle managers, especially in Student Affairs.

review_title: Great colleagues and students - administration is problematic
job_title: College Art Professor & Gallery Director in Portland, OR
pros: Supportive work environment. Autonomy in the classroom. Amazing students.
cons: As with all colleges these days, upward mobility into full-time/tenure-track positions is almost non-existent. Money is a constant source of problems at Clark and chronic cuts, especially to faculty, make for a constant feeling of job insecurity.

job_title: Customer Service Bookstore Clerk in Vancouver, WA
pros:
Helping new and returning students
Great work conditions
Loved working with Vicki Nier and other associates
cons: Stress, Busy at times, Professors who do not stipulate the books needed for their class

pros: Steady employment, retirement, vacation, sick days
cons: Low pay, politics, low employee appreciation

pros: The community of colleagues that I have the opportunity to work with is incredible. There is unity, resilience and commitment to service that remains throughout the multiple challenges faced in higher education student affairs.
cons: As in many organizations, bureaucratic structures and policies often hinder or infringe on the ability to serve students in a way that you would like to. I don't know that this is a con some much specific to Clark as it is to most institutions.

pros: Good students are interested in learning.
cons:
The culture violated the mission and vision...very toxic
Students slighted with prejudicial faculty

pros: Great work environment and great co-workers
cons: The pay is minimal and would not be enough to live on.

pros: Felt really listened to and they gave me free pretzels
cons: They sometimes make me run laps for exercise

review_title: While Clark was good, It has fallen in the last couple years
pros:
Some professors are helpful
Decent internet to do work
Advising does genuinely try to help, even if they aren't trained for the situation.
cons:
Some professors are down right rude and awful
Was unenrolled at random
Staff was not given the proper training

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Vancouver, WA
pros: Hours are great, especially for students.
cons: Can't come up with any, great first job.

review_title: Better than most, worse than some.
pros: Public sector, fantastic CIO, reasonable SLA, competitive wage.
cons: Some member of upper management are disconnected with realistic goals. Horrible inter-department communication.

pros: Great students and educators. Easy commute
cons: Not inclusive enough for staff of color

pros: Benefits for longtime adjuncts in the dept, some great individuals, strong ODEI
cons: white supremacy culture, hard to move up, hard to do social justice work, not a lot of power sharing, dept culture not warm or inviting

pros: There are off-times where you are able to study during work hours
cons: You need to be a patient person

pros: Many good things and some are great
cons: I have not been in jail

job_title: Community College Instructor in Vancouver, WA
pros: The only pro is that I don't work here anymore
cons: This place sucked years of my life away for nothing

pros: Everyone at Clark College really wants to see students succeed.
cons: The pay is low and raises are hard to come by.

review_title: Great place to work, if pay was better I'd still be there
pros: Clark had great people working there, like a big family.  Fun place to work.  I was in Admissions which included Student Recruitment and there were lots of cool events we planned for students. The Holiday Party was fun, and having the gym and beautiful campus to walk was really relaxing.
cons: The pay for support positions was REALLY low.  A great place to work but people in mid level positions don't leave often so there isn't a lot of room for movement. The ONE big downside was that because it’s higher education, education seems to be a REALLY big deal for staff.  Like if you have an AA degree you’re slightly better than someone with a 4th grade education and missing teeth, if you have a BA you are somewhat worth talking to, but are constantly asked when you’re going to enroll in your Masters program and if you have a Masters or Doctorate you officially can join the club.  It was a very elitist environment.

pros: Good mentors and directors here
cons: No real cons to working here

pros: None, that bad of a Place to work
cons: Upper management is terrible. Bad

review_title: This Place is a Slow Hell
pros: No one seems to care what you do? Flexible schedules.
cons: Psychological trauma, unfulfilling work environment, decisions made by people who don't know what they're doing. Lack of academic integrity, unmotivated students. College places no value on employees, especially those who are actually doing the teaching. All those who meet minimum qualifications are seen as interchangeable. Policies are enacted due to "budget" reasons that don't actually save money and harm students and employees alike. No one seems to have any idea how to run the place or pay anyone a decent wage. None of what you do in or out of the classroom matters. You could be a stellar teacher and you have no more value than someone who can't teach their way out of a box. They simply do not care. Retention rates and money are all that matter to them. Classes are dumbed down, students are misled, no one is really being "educated" - we move them on through so they can get "degrees". Despite administration constantly panicking over the budget, they make the most bizarre nonsensical cuts in an effort to correct things typically doing more damage in the process. (For example, they will cut fully enrolled classes due to "low enrollment". I know, right?)

job_title: Transitional Studies Instructor in Vancouver, WA
pros: Department Chair of Transitional Studies is nice and easy to talk to
cons: Too many ESL/ ELL students in ABE/GED courses.  ELL/ESL students have specific needs related to learning English and it is difficult to accommodate all students when they are combined into one course.

pros: The people that work there are great to work with. They also offer free tuition if you are in school, which is great. The pay was fair and the benefits were good.
cons: There are a lot of work study employees there, which can make it difficult to communicate sometimes because of always having to be trained.

pros: I love working here. Students and faculty are very friendly. Instructors and Admin are dedicated to the students. Great benefits.
cons: There isn't very much happening in Vancouver, Washington. The culinary program was shut down and there are a few food carts on campus but no cafeteria.

review_title: An important part of the community
pros: My experice working for Clark College was a positive one. They really are a big part of Vancouver community, and they have added a lot to their programs to serve a wider range of people who are looking to advance academically or to gain a skill.
cons: The pay was not vey good, but this was not their fault as the budget cuts were in full effect.

pros: Great benefits, many good programs for students, local and diverse. Many training opportunities for employees to futher their skills; opportunities to move around are available.
cons: Terrible morale and too much uppper management. When in a budget crisis, all the work is put on lower level staff which results in many good employees leaving.

pros: There are some really good people at Clark College who truly care about student success.  However, those people are typically not in leadership positions and are too few and far between.
cons: Too many to count.  Systems that don't allow for students to be successful.  Constant employee turnover due to lack of pay and poor work environment.

review_title: Great place to start in Higher Education
job_title: Student Affairs Employee in Vancouver, WA
pros: Gain experience working with diverse student populations, good entry-level opportunities, flexibility with making mistakes with no real consequences
cons: Pay is 30% less than you'd make with other colleges/universities in the area for the equivalent job title, too many "old white men" mentalities, some staff are semi-incompetent

job_title: RN Charge Nurse in Portland, OR
pros: many competent staff, good to work with, good salary, ability to grow with the position, some great doctors
cons: benefits not up to area, not able to up staffing with patient acuity, manager not up with standards of care, no continuing education for the field in hospital

pros: Wonderful people and campus. A true feeling of being part of the community.
cons: Mismanagement at the executive level. Lack of communication from management. Not much opportunity for career advancement.

review_title: Worst 'inclusive environment' and upper management. A complete joke
job_title: Financial Aid Specialist in Vancouver, WA
pros:
Middle management was some of the greatest I have had. My manager were very hands off and trusted me with my program. My managers were also forgiving with mistakes and were always available for help when you needed it. 
My managers and office were extremely flexible with taking time off, taking sick time, and general work schedule options. 
One great perk for all full time employees is the free tuition waver. Most managers are flexible on your schedule when wanting to take a class on campus during working hours. 
All of my coworkers were nice and caring. I hardly had an issue with the people that I worked with day to day. I felt like I had an office family. 
May consider this a pro or not, but Clark is extremely slow with work. All day every day except maybe a few weeks out of every year before a new quarter starts. Clark's "crazy busy" days are probably equivalent to a slow day in the private sector. Things would get very boring very fast. 
Medical benefits are very competitive.
cons:
Upper management. The upper management in my office and across Clark makes higher education look bad (mostly because they all have higher educations themselves). Some are hired with very little to no skill set in the field that they were hired for. When the top has been complaining about how bad department leadership is by multiple employees, they just ignore it.
Things move extremely slow at Clark. Mainly because of my earlier point that most upper management is very incompetent in the field they have been placed in.
Clark has gone through a lot of bad media periods about racial inclusion issues. Being a Hispanic women, all I have noticed at Clark is a loud outspoken distaste for 'white men'. Usually these would be words spoken directly from a department leadership's mouth in front of white male employees. "Why do you need a raise? White men have been privileged for so long, they don't need a raise". This was said to my coworker who is a white male and who is also a great hardworking employee. Working at Clark has made me experience what real life racism really is. I cannot tell you how many employees talk about how wrong this is to each other but yet do not have the courage to speak out and appear to be going against the 'inclusive environment'. 
Pay is extremely low. I cannot imagine how someone with kids lives on the salary. The salary is not competitive with other schools. 
There is a cap at how much you growth, learn and expand as an employee at Clark. Work is usually the same thing everyday unless you are in management. Not a place to grow or stay if you are wanting to advance in your career. At a certain point, it becomes wasted time, if you are someone who is wanting to grow.

pros: This is one of the best part time jobs I've ever had. I make 17.60 an hour and work about 16 hours a week.
cons: I believe most of the other jobs at Clark pay around 10 an hour. There isn't much opportunity for advancement in the security department.

pros: Pleasant coworkers and management; manageable workload; not stressful atmosphere.
cons: Work-study employment doesn't allow for upward mobility or job retention after graduation; little communication between college departments.

review_title: An inclusive and friendly work environment
pros: Willing to work with you and they are very inclusive.
cons: The downside to the company is I was unable to switch from a part-time employee to full-time and they were unable to find a position within the company for me. This isn't their fault though since they are funded by grants.

pros: They respect and support adjunct professors. They offer many opportunities for professional development, some with stipends for attending.  Very committed to diversity and inclusion. Also committed to getting teachers to learn the best methods for teaching using active learning.
cons: Not many opportunities for full time work- large percent of workforce is adjunct.

review_title: Stable and Predictable Place to Work
job_title: Campus Security Officer in Vancouver, WA
pros: Benefits package, retirement program, educational opportunities, supportive department and supervisors.
cons: Increasing political correctness culture, operations not proactive enough in problem solving but has at times surges of activity (not consistent).

pros:
Beautiful campus
Food options on campus
Friendly and inviting work environment
cons: Limited upward mobility and bloated management.

job_title: Work Study Program Coordinator in Vancouver, WA
pros: Employees are like family. Can attend college while working.
cons: State job but compensation is very low. If you do less work you get more compensation.

review_title: Good but not GREAT, great but not fantastic
pros: Flexible hours, great people, and get to teach a sunkect
cons: Multiple supervisors, fellow tutors & theirchild like attitudes

pros: Team oriented staff with a way to have fun too. They have pride in their employees and due their best to accommodate everyone's needs.
cons: Hard to advance to full time employment unless someone leaves their position for an opening.

pros: The staff here is a pleasure to be around, they are very forthcoming with information and they just want you to be the best instructor you can be.
cons: The only down side is there are not enough classes to go around.

review_title: Great facilities and resources for faculty and students for Community College
pros: Clark really makes huge efforts to support its students and faculty in order to retain and have students succeed.
cons: Adjuncts can't teach over 50% full time for consecutive terms.

review_title: Clark College is a nice place to work
pros: A generally nice working environment with generally nice people. Having worked here for nearly a year, I can honestly say that it's a non-demanding and nice place to work.
cons: I don't have any meaningful complaints.

review_title: A nice start for people who want to pursue a career in higher education

cons: The pay is not very good, but what else can you expect from the receptionist position

pros: Access to the college environment
